name: django
short_description: An introduction to Django, a Python web framework

lessons.name: Getting Started
lessons.completion: So far so good. You now have a functioning Django server. In the next lesson, we'll create our first webpage.

tasks.instruction: First, use pip to install Django.
Now, use the django-admin.py script to start a project. Enter django-admin.py startproject <name>.
tasks.hint: Make sure django-admin.py is on your $PATH. Starting a trolley app would look like `django-admin.py startproject trolley`.

tasks.instruction: Now that you have a starting application, test your configuration by running `<project_name>/manage.py runserver.
tasks.hint: Try changing directories to your project and running `python manage.py runserver`.

lessons.name: Writing your first view
lessons.completion: Great job! If you open `localhost:8000` in a web browser, you'll see the Django equivalent of `hello world`. In our next lesson, we'll explore Django apps and create a database.

tasks.instruction: As you might have noticed, the 'It worked!' page said 'you are seeing this page because you have not configured any urls'. This is referring to the urls.py in <project_name>/<project_name>. Change to that directory and look at urls.py using `cat`.
tasks.hint:
To get to the right directory, enter:
`cd <project_name>/<project_name>`
And to look at urls.py:
`cat urls.py`.

tasks.instruction: On the fourth line, you'll notice a url that is commented out. Uncomment it, and change the middle string to 'views.home' from '<project_name.views.home>.
tasks.hint:
The urls.py file should look like this when you're done:
from django.conf.urls import patterns, include, url

from django.contrib import admin
admin.autodiscover()

urlpatterns = patterns('',
	# Examples:
	url(r'^$', 'views.home', name='home'),
	...).

Don't worry about the `admin`. We'll cover that later.
`views.py` should be on the same level as urls.py.
